articles.headline: Google Deal Divides Travel Industry
articles.snippet: Some think Google’s proposed purchase of ITA, the provider of flight data, would produce helpful innovation, but others worry about an oppressive domination of travel search.
articles.abstract: Some think Google’s proposed purchase of ITA, the provider of flight data, would produce helpful innovation, but others worry about an oppressive domination of travel search.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has a knack for making waves when it pushes into new arenas, and online travel is no exception. Six months ago, Google announced its intention to buy the company that made it easy for travelers to compare airfares, ITA Software, for $700 million.

articles.headline: Michigan Town Is Left Pleading for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Leaders of Hamtramck, a working-class city near Detroit, are looking for something to cut from a budget that’s already been cut, over and over.
articles.abstract: Leaders of Hamtramck, a working-class city near Detroit, are looking for something to cut from a budget that’s already been cut, over and over.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMTRAMCK, Mich. — Leaders of this city met for more than seven hours on a Saturday not long ago, searching for something to cut from a budget that has already been cut, over and over.

articles.headline: Flashy Office Space, Advertising India’s Allure
articles.snippet: India appears to be at the point where offices are meant to advertise the nation’s arrival on the world stage.
articles.abstract: India appears to be at the point where offices are meant to advertise the nation’s arrival on the world stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIRUSERI, India  A massive futuristic office complex is rising from a patch of spare, arid land here near the southern Indian city of Chennai. Six butterfly-shaped buildings dock like spacecraft to two long metal-latticed terminals.

articles.headline: Disney Tackles Major Theme Park Problem: Lines
articles.snippet: An underground high-tech nerve center at Disney World addresses the most low-tech of problems: long waits.
articles.abstract: An underground high-tech nerve center at Disney World addresses the most low-tech of problems: long waits.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla.  Deep in the bowels of Walt Disney World, inside an underground bunker called the Disney Operational Command Center, technicians know that you are standing in line and that you are most likely annoyed about it. Their clandestine mission: to get you to the fun faster.

articles.headline: Retail Sales Rebound, Beating Forecasts
articles.snippet: Shoppers spent more this holiday season than at any time since before the recession, according to preliminary data.
articles.abstract: Shoppers spent more this holiday season than at any time since before the recession, according to preliminary data.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are splurging as though it’s 2007 again.

articles.headline: A Venezuelan Oasis of Elitism Counts Its Days
articles.snippet: The idyll of the Caracas Country Club seems intact, but beneath the veneer of tranquility, there is a fear that the government will expropriate the premises.
articles.abstract: The idyll of the Caracas Country Club seems intact, but beneath the veneer of tranquility, there is a fear that the government will expropriate the premises.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  The golfers still argue over handicaps. The waiters still serve flutes of Moët & Chandon. Sunlight still kisses the grounds laid out in the 1920s by Olmsted Brothers, the esteemed American landscape architects.

articles.headline: In Russia, an Advocate Is Killed, and an Accuser Tried
articles.snippet: A human rights figure who made accusations against Chechnya’s president in the death of Natalya K. Estemirova was himself put on trial, for defamation.
articles.abstract: A human rights figure who made accusations against Chechnya’s president in the death of Natalya K. Estemirova was himself put on trial, for defamation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  In a small courtroom in Moscow, friends of Natalya K. Estemirova crowded onto wooden benches, clasping photographs of her. It was 16 months after the murder of Ms. Estemirova, a renowned human rights advocate in the tumultuous region of Chechnya, and now the legal system was taking action.
